name: Titanium.UI.TableView
summary: A table view is used to present information, organized in sections and rows, in a vertically-scrolling view.

events.name: swipe
events.summary: Fired when the device detects a swipe gesture (left or right) against the view.

properties.name: direction
properties.summary: Direction of the swipe, either `left` or `right`.

properties.name: index
properties.summary: Row index.

properties.name: row
properties.summary: Table view row object.

properties.name: rowData
x
properties.summary: X coordinate of the event's endpoint from the `source` view's coordinate system.

properties.name: y
properties.summary: Y coordinate of the event's endpoint from the `source` view's coordinate system.

properties.name: bubbles
properties.summary: True if the event will try to bubble up if possible.

properties.name: cancelBubble
properties.summary: Set to true to stop the event from bubbling.

properties.name: source
properties.summary: Source object that fired the event.

properties.name: type
properties.summary: Name of the event fired.

events.name: twofingertap
events.summary: Fired when the device detects a two-finger tap against the view.

properties.name: x
properties.summary: X coordinate of the event from the `source` view's coordinate system.

properties.name: y
properties.summary: Y coordinate of the event from the `source` view's coordinate system.

properties.name: bubbles
properties.summary: True if the event will try to bubble up if possible.

properties.name: cancelBubble
properties.summary: Set to true to stop the event from bubbling.

properties.name: source
properties.summary: Source object that fired the event.

properties.name: type
properties.summary: Name of the event fired.

events.name: touchstart
events.summary: Fired as soon as the device detects a touch gesture against this view.
events.description: On Android and iOS, be aware that a row or table touch event and a table scroll event cannot occur concurrently. If a table begins to scroll during a touch event, the appropriate row or table touchcancel event fire before the scroll event begins.

properties.name: index
properties.summary: Row index.

properties.name: row
properties.summary: Table view row object.

properties.name: rowData
x
properties.summary: X coordinate of the event from the `source` view's coordinate system.

properties.name: y
properties.summary: Y coordinate of the event from the `source` view's coordinate system.

properties.name: force
properties.summary:
The current force value of the touch event.
Note: This property only available for iOS devices that support 3D-Touch and run 9.0 or later.

properties.name: maximumPossibleForce
properties.summary:
Maximum possible value of the force property.
Note: This property is only available for iOS devices that support 3D-Touch and run 9.0 or later.

properties.name: altitudeAngle
properties.summary:
A value which indicates the stylus angle on the screen. If the stylus is perpendicular to the screen or no stylus is
being used, the value will be Pi/2. If the stylus is parallel to the screen, the value will be 0.
Note: This property is only available for iOS devices that support 3D-Touch and are 9.1 or later.

properties.name: timestamp
properties.summary:
The time (in seconds) when the touch was used in correlation with the system start up.
 Note: This property is only available for iOS devices that support 3D-Touch and run 9.0 or later.

properties.name: bubbles
properties.summary: True if the event will try to bubble up if possible.

properties.name: cancelBubble
properties.summary: Set to true to stop the event from bubbling.

properties.name: source
properties.summary: Source object that fired the event.

properties.name: type
properties.summary: Name of the event fired.

events.name: touchcancel
events.summary: Fired when a touch gesture is interrupted by the device.
events.description:
Generated in various circumstances, including an incoming call to allow the UI to clean up state.

On Android and iOS, be aware that a row or table touch event and a table scroll event cannot occur concurrently. If a table begins to scroll during a touch event, the appropriate row or table touchcancel event fire before the scroll event begins.

properties.name: x
properties.summary: X coordinate of the event from the `source` view's coordinate system.

properties.name: y
properties.summary: Y coordinate of the event from the `source` view's coordinate system.

properties.name: force
properties.summary:
The current force value of the touch event.
Note: This property only available for iOS devices that support 3D-Touch and run 9.0 or later.

properties.name: maximumPossibleForce
properties.summary:
Maximum possible value of the force property.
Note: This property is only available for iOS devices that support 3D-Touch and run 9.0 or later.

properties.name: altitudeAngle
properties.summary:
A value which indicates the stylus angle on the screen. If the stylus is perpendicular to the screen or no stylus is
being used, the value will be Pi/2. If the stylus is parallel to the screen, the value will be 0.
Note: This property is only available for iOS devices that support 3D-Touch and are 9.1 or later.

properties.name: timestamp
properties.summary:
The time (in seconds) when the touch was used in correlation with the system start up.
 Note: This property is only available for iOS devices that support 3D-Touch and run 9.0 or later.

properties.name: bubbles
properties.summary: True if the event will try to bubble up if possible.

properties.name: cancelBubble
properties.summary: Set to true to stop the event from bubbling.

properties.name: source
properties.summary: Source object that fired the event.

properties.name: type
properties.summary: Name of the event fired.

events.name: touchend
events.summary: Fired when a touch gesture is complete.
events.description: On Android and iOS, be aware that a row or table touch event and a table scroll event cannot occur concurrently. If a table begins to scroll during a touch event, the appropriate row or table touchcancel event fire before the scroll event begins.

The current force value of the touch event.
Note: This property only available for iOS devices that support 3D-Touch and run 9.0 or later.

properties.name: altitudeAngle

A value which indicates the stylus angle on the screen. If the stylus is perpendicular to the screen or no stylus is
being used, the value will be Pi/2. If the stylus is parallel to the screen, the value will be 0.
Note: This property is only available for iOS devices that support 3D-Touch and are 9.1 or later.

properties.name: timestamp

The time (in seconds) when the touch was used in correlation with the system start up.
 Note: This property is only available for iOS devices that support 3D-Touch and run 9.0 or later.

properties.name: bubbles
properties.summary: True if the event will try to bubble up if possible.

properties.name: cancelBubble
properties.summary: Set to true to stop the event from bubbling.

properties.name: source
properties.summary: Source object that fired the event.

properties.name: type
properties.summary: Name of the event fired.

events.name: click
events.summary: Fired when a table row is clicked by the user.
events.description:
There is a subtle difference between singletap and click events.

A singletap event is generated when the user taps the screen briefly without moving their finger. This gesture will also generate a click event.

However, a click event can also be generated when the user touches, moves their finger, and then removes it from the screen.

On Android, a click event can also be generated by a trackball click.

properties.name: detail
properties.summary:
Indicates whether the detail button was clicked. Only `true` if `row.hasDetail` is
`true` and the detail button was clicked.

properties.name: index
properties.summary: Row index.

properties.name: row
properties.summary: Table view row object.

properties.name: rowData
searchMode
properties.summary: Indicates whether the table is in search mode.

properties.name: section
properties.summary: Table view section object, if the clicked row is contained in a section.

properties.name: x
properties.summary: X coordinate of the event from the `source` view's coordinate system.

properties.name: y
properties.summary: Y coordinate of the event from the `source` view's coordinate system.

properties.name: bubbles
properties.summary: True if the event will try to bubble up if possible.

properties.name: cancelBubble
properties.summary: Set to true to stop the event from bubbling.

properties.name: source
properties.summary: Source object that fired the event.

properties.name: type
properties.summary: Name of the event fired.

events.name: longpress
events.summary: Fired when the device detects a long press.
events.description:
A long press is generated by touching and holding on the touchscreen. Unlike a longclick, it does not respond to the trackball button.

The event occurs before the finger is lifted.

A longpress and a longclick can occur together.

In contrast to a longclick, this event returns the x and y coordinates of the touch.

properties.summary: Row index.

properties.name: row
properties.summary: Table view row object.

y

properties.summary: Indicates whether the delete button was clicked. Always `false` for this event.

properties.

properties.summary: Indicates whether the table is in search mode. Always `false` for this event.

properties.name: section

properties.summary: X coordinate of the event from the `source` view's coordinate system.

properties.name: y

events.name: indexclick
events.summary: Fired when the index bar is clicked by the user.
events.description: If the tabe view contains the index array of indices the index bar will appear on the side. This event will fire when this bar is clicked

properties.name: title
properties.summary: The title of the index clicked.

properties.name: index
properties.summary: The index number clicked.

properties.name: bubbles
properties.summary: True if the event will try to bubble up if possible.

properties.name: cancelBubble
properties.summary: Set to true to stop the event from bubbling.

properties.name: source
properties.summary: Source object that fired the event.

properties.name: type
properties.summary: Name of the event fired.

events.name: move
events.summary: Fired when a table row is moved by the user.

properties.name: detail
properties.summary: Boolean to indicate if the right area was clicked. Always `false` for this event.

properties.name: index
properties.summary: Row index.

properties.name: searchMode
properties.summary: Boolean to indicate if the table is in search mode. Always `false` for this event.

properties.name: section
properties.summary: Table view section object, if the deleted row is contained in a section.

properties.name: row
properties.summary: Table view row object.

properties.name: rowData
properties.summary:
Properties of the row. Use this property rather than `row` to access any custom row
properties.

properties.name: x
properties.summary: X coordinate of the event from the `source` view's coordinate system.

properties.name: y
properties.summary: Y coordinate of the event from the `source` view's coordinate system.

properties.name: bubbles
properties.summary: True if the event will try to bubble up if possible.

properties.name: cancelBubble
properties.summary: Set to true to stop the event from bubbling.

properties.name: source
properties.summary: Source object that fired the event.

properties.name: type

events.name: dragstart
events.summary: Fired when the scrollable region starts being dragged.
events.description: A dragging gesture is when a touch remains in contact with the display to physically drag the view, as opposed to it being the result of scrolling momentum.

events.name: dragend
events.summary: Fired when the scrollable region stops being dragged.
events.description: A dragging gesture is when a touch remains in contact with the display to physically drag the view, as opposed to it being the result of scrolling momentum.

properties.name: decelerate
properties.summary:
Indicates whether scrolling will continue but decelerate, now that the drag gesture has
been released by the touch. If `false`, scrolling will stop immediately.

properties.name: bubbles
properties.summary: True if the event will try to bubble up if possible.

properties.name: cancelBubble
properties.summary: Set to true to stop the event from bubbling.

properties.name: source
properties.summary: Source object that fired the event.

properties.name: type
properties.summary: Name of the event fired.

events.name: scroll
events.summary: Fired when the table view is scrolled.

properties.name: contentOffset
properties.summary: Dictionary with `x` and `y` properties containing the content offset.

properties.name: contentSize
properties.summary:
Dictionary with `width` and `height` properties containing the size of the content
(regardless of the display size in the case of scrolling).

properties.name: firstVisibleItem
properties.summary: Row index of the topmost visible row in the view.

properties.name: size
properties.summary:
Dictionary with `width` and `height` properties containing the size of the visible
table view

properties.name: totalItemCount
properties.summary: Total number of rows in the view.

properties.name: visibleItemCount
properties.summary: Number of rows currently visible in the view.

properties.name: bubbles
properties.summary: True if the event will try to bubble up if possible.

properties.name: cancelBubble
properties.summary: Set to true to stop the event from bubbling.

properties.name: source
properties.summary: Source object that fired the event.

properties.name: type
properties.summary: Name of the event fired.

events.name: scrollend
events.summary: Fired when the table view stops scrolling.

properties.name: contentSize
properties.summary:
Dictionary with `width` and `height` properties containing the size of the content
(regardless of the display size in the case of scrolling).

properties.name: contentOffset
properties.summary: Dictionary with `x` and `y` properties containing the content offset.

properties.name: size
properties.summary:
Dictionary with `width` and `height` properties containing the size of the visible
table view.

properties.name: x
properties.summary: X coordinate of the event from the `source` view's coordinate system.

properties.name: y
properties.summary: Y coordinate of the event from the `source` view's coordinate system.

properties.name: bubbles

methods.name: appendRow
methods.summary: Appends a single row or an array of rows to the end of the table.
methods.description:
Each row can be passed as a Titanium.UI.TableViewRow object, or as dictionary specifying the properties for a table row, in which case this TableView will create TableViewRow objects as needed.

On iOS, the row(s) can be inserted with animation by specifying a properties parameter.

parameters.name: row
parameters.summary: Row or rows to add to the table.

methods.name: appendSection
methods.summary: Appends a single section or an array of sections to the end of the table.
methods.description:
Each section can be passed as a Titanium.UI.TableViewSection object, or as dictionary specifying the properties for a table section, in which case this TableView will create TableViewSection objects as needed.

On iOS, the section(s) can be inserted with animation by specifying a properties parameter.

Due to a known issue, TIMOB-12616, this method should not be used for adding sections on iOS.

parameters.name: section
parameters.summary: Section or section to add to the table.

methods.name: deleteRow
methods.description: On iOS, the row can be deleted with animation by specifying a properties parameter. Starting in SDK 3.1.0, the row can be specified using Titanium.UI.TableViewRow on Android and iOS.

parameters.name: row
parameters.summary: Index of the row to delete, or the row object to delete.

methods.name: deleteSection
methods.description: On iOS, the section can be deleted with animation by specifying a properties parameter.

parameters.name: section
parameters.summary: Index of the section to delete.

methods.name: insertRowAfter
methods.description:
Each row can be passed as a Titanium.UI.TableViewRow object, or as dictionary specifying the properties for a table row, in which case this TableView will create TableViewRow objects as needed.

On iOS, the row(s) may be inserted with animation by setting the animation parameter.

parameters.name: index
parameters.summary: Index of the row to insert after.

methods.name: insertRowBefore
methods.description:
Each row can be passed as a Titanium.UI.TableViewRow object, or as dictionary specifying the properties for a table row, in which case this TableView will create TableViewRow objects as needed.

On iOS, the row(s) may be inserted with animation by setting the animation parameter.

parameters.name: index
parameters.summary: Index of the row to insert before.

methods.name: insertSectionAfter
methods.description:
Each section can be passed as a Titanium.UI.TableViewSection object, or as dictionary specifying the properties for a table section, in which case this TableView will create TableViewSection objects as needed.

On iOS, the section(s) may be inserted with animation by setting the animation parameter.

Due to a known issue, TIMOB-12616, this method should not be used for adding sections on iOS.

parameters.name: index
parameters.summary: Index of the section to insert after.

methods.name: insertSectionBefore
methods.description:
Each section can be passed as a Titanium.UI.TableViewSection object, or as dictionary specifying the properties for a table section, in which case this TableViewSection will create TableViewSection objects as needed.

On iOS, the section(s) may be inserted with animation by setting the animation parameter.

Due to a known issue, TIMOB-12616, this method should not be used for adding sections on iOS.

parameters.name: index
parameters.summary: Index of the section to insert before.

methods.name: scrollToIndex
methods.summary: Scrolls the table view to ensure that the specified row is on screen.
methods.description: On iOS, specify a TableViewAnimationProperties object to control the position that the selected row is scrolled to, and whether scrolling is animated.

methods.name: scrollToTop
methods.summary: Scrolls the table to a specific top position where 0 is the topmost y position in the table view.
methods.description:
The behavior of this method is platform-specific.

On Android, the top value is interpreted as a row index that should be scrolled to the top of the screen. The table will not scroll the last row of data higher than the bottom of the screen. If there is less than one screenful of data below the specified row, the table doesn't scroll the specified row all the way to the top. If the table has less than one screenful of data total, it does not scroll at all.

On iOS, the top value is interpreted as a pixel offset between the top of the top row of data and the top of the table view. So a top value of 0 scrolls the list to the top. A positive value scrolls it down, and a negative value scrolls the list up above the first item.

On iOS, specify a TableViewAnimationProperties object with animated set to false to disable the scrolling animation.

parameters.name: top
parameters.summary: Y position for the top of the table view.

methods.name: selectRow
methods.summary: Programmatically selects a row. In Android, it sets the currently selected item. If in touch mode, the item will not be selected but it will still be positioned appropriately. If the specified selection position is less than 0, then the item at position 0 will be selected.

methods.name: setContentInsets
methods.description:
A table view is essentially a scroll view that contains a set of static row views that represents the content. Thus, the setContentInsets method facilitates a margin, or inset, distance between the content and the container scroll view.

Typically used with the headerPullView property.

parameters.name: animated
parameters.summary: Determines whether, and how, the content inset change should be animated.

methods.name: setContentOffset
methods.summary: Sets the value of the content offset of the table view without animation by default.

parameters.name: contentOffset
parameters.summary:
Dictionary with the properties `x`, `y`, and `animated`. The `x` and `y` coordinates
reposition the top-left point of the scrollable region of the table view.
The `animated` property is optional and set to `false` by default.

methods.name: setData
methods.description:
Each row can be passed as a Titanium.UI.TableViewRow object, or as dictionary specifying the properties for a table row, in which case this TableView will create TableViewRow objects as needed.

setData can also be used to add Titanium.UI.TableViewSections to a table view.

parameters.name: data
parameters.summary: Rows or sections to add to this table.

methods.name: updateRow
methods.summary: Updates an existing row, optionally with animation.

parameters.name: index
parameters.summary: Index of the row to update.

methods.name: updateSection
methods.summary: Updates an existing section, optionally with animation.
methods.description:
Known issues:

  • On iOS, event listeners do not fire correctly after table view sections are updated using the updateSection methods. (TIMOB-12616

parameters.name: index
parameters.summary: Index of the section to update.

properties.name: search
properties.summary: Determines whether this table's rows can be selected.
properties.description: Set to false to prevent rows from being selected.

properties.name: allowsSelectionDuringEditing
properties.summary: Determines whether this table's rows can be selected while editing the table.
properties.description: Set to true to allow rows to be selected.

properties.name: backgroundColor
properties.summary: Background color of the view, as a color name or hex triplet.
properties.description: For information about color values, see the "Colors" section of Titanium.UI.
properties.default: transparent on non-iOS platforms, white on the iOS platform

properties.name: data
properties.summary: Rows of the table view.

properties.name: dimBackgroundForSearch
properties.summary: A Boolean indicating whether the underlying content is dimmed during a search.
properties.description: If you do not want to show the dimmed background when clicking on the search bar, set this property false during creation.

properties.name: editable
properties.summary: Determines the rows' default editable behavior, which allows them to be deleted by the user when the table is in editing or moving mode.
properties.description:
This property determines the default behavior of child rows, but may be overridden by a row's editable property.

See the Titanium.UI.TableView description section for a full explanation of the TableView's editing and moving modes.

properties.name: editing
properties.summary: Determines whether row editing mode is active.
properties.description:
The editing mode allows rows to be deleted or re-ordered, depending on their editable and moveable settings.

See the Titanium.UI.TableView description section for a full explanation of the TableView's editing and moving modes.

properties.name: filterAnchored
properties.summary: Determines whether the search is limited to the start of the string
properties.description: Set to true to enable case anchored search.

properties.name: filterAttribute
properties.summary: Filter attribute to be used when searching.
properties.description:
On the Android platform, this property can only be set to Titanium-defined properties of the TableViewRow object, such as title. To search text stored in a different attribute, set the title property of the TableViewRow object to the property to be searched. For example:

var label = Ti.UI.createLabel({text: 'Foobar'}),
var row = Ti.UI.createTableViewRow(title: label.text);
row.add(label);

On the iOS platform, this property can be set to any property on the TableViewRow object, including arbitrary properties set on the object, not only Titanium-defined properties.

Note that the filter is not anchored to the beginning of the string. So typing "ha" in the text box will include rows titled 'Harold' and 'Harvard', but also 'Sharon' and 'Jonathan'.

properties.name: filterCaseInsensitive
properties.summary: Determines whether the search is case insensitive.
properties.description: Set to false to enable case sensitive search.

properties.name: footerDividersEnabled
properties.summary: When set to false, the ListView will not draw the divider before the footer view.

properties.name: footerTitle
properties.summary: Table view footer title.

properties.name: footerView
properties.summary: Table view footer as a view that will be rendered instead of a label.
properties.description:
In Alloy you can use a <FooterView> element nested in a <TableView> element:

<Alloy>
    <TableView>
        <FooterView>
            <View backgroundColor="#a00" height="50dp"/>
        </FooterView>
        <TableViewRow><Label>Row 1</Label></TableViewRow>
        <TableViewRow><Label>Row 2</Label></TableViewRow>
    </TableView>
</Alloy>

properties.name: headerDividersEnabled
properties.summary: When set to false, the ListView will not draw the divider after the header view.

properties.name: headerPullView
properties.summary: View positioned above the first row that is only revealed when the user drags the table contents down.
properties.description:
A headerPullView is a UI control that is often used to provide a convenient way for the user to refresh a table's data. Typically used with the setContentInsets method.

To specify the wrapper color see pullBackgroundColor.

For an example, see the "Pull to refresh" section in the TableViews guide.

Alloy applications can use a <HeaderPullView> element inside a <TableView> element.

<Alloy>
    <TableView>
        <HeaderPullView platform="ios">
            <View class="pull">
                <Label color="#F2F4F4" bottom="25dp">Header pull view</Label>
            </View>
        </HeaderPullView>
    </TableView>
</Alloy>

properties.name: headerTitle
properties.summary: Table view header title.

properties.name: headerView
properties.summary: Table view header as a view that will be rendered instead of a label.
properties.description:
In Alloy you can use a <HeaderView> element nested in a <TableView> element:

<Alloy>
    <TableView>
        <HeaderView>
            <View backgroundColor="#a00" height="50dp"/>
        </HeaderView>
        <TableViewRow><Label>Row 1</Label></TableViewRow>
        <TableViewRow><Label>Row 2</Label></TableViewRow>
    </TableView>
</Alloy>

properties.name: hideSearchOnSelection
properties.summary: Determines whether the search field should hide on completion.
properties.description:
Set to false to prevent the search field from being hidden when an item in the search results is clicked.

Many standard applications (such as Contacts) have a behavior equivalent to false for this value, but the default is true for legacy reasons.

The Android platform behaves as though this value were false.

properties.name: index
properties.summary: Array of objects (with title and index properties) to control the table view index.
properties.description: If an index array is specified, an index bar is displayed on the right-hand side of the table view. Clicking on a title in the index bar scrolls the table view to the row index associated with that title. If the index is -1 the table view will scroll to the top.

properties.name: maxClassname
properties.summary: Max number of row class names.
properties.description: See className for more details. This property will default to 32 when it is set to a number lesser than that.

properties.name: maxRowHeight
properties.summary: Maximum row height for table view rows.

properties.name: minRowHeight
properties.summary: Minimum row height for table view rows.

properties.name: moveable
properties.summary: Determines the rows' default moveable behavior, which allows them to be re-ordered by the user when the table is in editing or moving mode.
properties.description:
This property determines the default behavior of child rows, but may be overridden by a row's moveable property.

See the Titanium.UI.TableView description section for a full explanation of the TableView's editing and moving modes.

properties.name: moving
properties.summary: Determines whether row moving mode is active.
properties.description:
The moving mode allows rows to be deleted or re-ordered, depending on their editable and moveable settings.

See the Titanium.UI.TableView description section for a full explanation of the TableView's editing and moving modes.

properties.name: overScrollMode
properties.summary: Determines the behavior when the user overscrolls the view.

properties.name: refreshControl
properties.summary: View positioned above the first row that is only revealed when the user drags the list view contents down.
properties.description: An alternate to the headerPullView property. See Titanium.UI.RefreshControl for usage and examples.

properties.name: resultsBackgroundColor
properties.summary: The background color of the search results (iOS-only).
properties.description: For information about color values, see the "Colors" section of Titanium.UI. Note: A transparent background-color is not officially supported by Apple to prevent that the list of results overlaps with the list view below it.

properties.name: resultsSeparatorColor
properties.summary: Separator line color between rows inside search results, as a color name or hex triplet (iOS-only).
properties.description: To make the line invisible, set this property to transparent, or the same value as the backgroundColor property. For information about color values, see the "Colors" section of Titanium.UI.

properties.name: resultsSeparatorInsets
properties.summary: The insets for search results separators (applies to all cells & iOS-only).
properties.description: Cell separators do not extend all the way to the edge of the list view. This property sets the default inset for all cells in the table. Set this to a dictionary with two keys, left specifying inset from left edge and right specifying the inset from the right edge.

properties.name: resultsSeparatorStyle
properties.summary: The separator style of the search results (iOS-only).

properties.name: rowHeight
properties.summary: Default row height for table view rows.

properties.name: rowSeparatorInsets
properties.summary: The insets for table view cells (applies to all cells).
properties.description:
Cell separators do not extend all the way to the edge of the table view.Set this to a dictionary with two keys, left specifying inset from left edge and right specifying the inset from the right edge. This property is only available upon creation of the cells.

For example:

tableView1.setRowSeparatorInsets({
    left:10,
    right:10
});

properties.name: scrollable
properties.summary: If true, the tableview can be scrolled.

properties.name: scrollIndicatorStyle
properties.summary: Style of the scrollbar.

properties.name: scrollsToTop
properties.summary: Controls whether the scroll-to-top gesture is effective.
properties.description: The scroll-to-top gesture is a tap on the status bar; The default value of this property is true. This gesture works when you have a single visible table view. If there are multiple table views, web views, text areas, and/or scroll views visible, you will need to disable (set to false) on the above views you DON'T want this behaviour on. The remaining view will then respond to scroll-to-top gesture.

properties.name: search
properties.summary: Search field to use for the table view.
properties.description:
In an Alloy application, you can use a <SearchView> or <SearchBar> element inside a <TableView> element.

<Alloy>
    <TableView>
      <!-- search, shorthand with Ti.UI.SearchBar -->
      <SearchBar platform="ios"/>
      <!-- search, shorthand with Ti.UI.Android.SearchView -->
      <SearchView ns="Ti.UI.Android" platform="android"/>
    </TableView>
</Alloy>

properties.name: searchAsChild
properties.summary: Determines whether the Titanium.UI.SearchBar or Titanium.UI.Android.SearchView appears as part of the TableView.
properties.description: Set to false if the search view will be displayed in the action bar.

properties.name: searchHidden
properties.summary: Determines whether the search field is visible.
properties.description: Set to true to hide the search field.

properties.name: sectionCount
properties.summary: Number of sections in this table view.

properties.name: sections
properties.summary: Sections of this table.
properties.description:
In Release 3.0, this property is read-only on Android.

Due to a known issue, TIMOB-12616, the sections property should not be used for adding sections on iOS.

properties.name: separatorColor
properties.summary: Separator line color between rows, as a color name or hex triplet.
properties.description:
To make the line invisible, set this property to transparent, or the same value as the backgroundColor property.

For information about color values, see the "Colors" section of Titanium.UI.

properties.name: separatorInsets
properties.summary: The insets for table view separators (applies to all cells).
properties.description:
Cell separators do not extend all the way to the edge of the table view. This property sets the default inset for all cells in the table. Set this to a dictionary with two keys, left specifying inset from left edge and right specifying the inset from the right edge.

For example:

tableView1.setSeparatorInsets({
    left:10,
    right:10
});

properties.name: separatorStyle
properties.summary: Separator style constant.

properties.name: showVerticalScrollIndicator
properties.summary: Determines whether this table view displays a vertical scroll indicator.
properties.description: Set to false to hide the vertical scroll indicator.

properties.name: style
properties.summary: Style of the table view, specified using one of the constants from Titanium.UI.iOS.TableViewStyle.
properties.description: Style should always be set before setting the data on table view.

properties.name: tableSeparatorInsets
properties.summary: The insets for the table view header and footer.
properties.description:
Cell separators do not extend all the way to the edge of the table view.Set this to a dictionary with two keys, left specifying inset from left edge and right specifying the inset from the right edge. If the rowSeparatorInsets is not set, the tableSeparatorInsets will also set the cell insets.

For example:

tableView1.setTableSeparatorInsets({
    left:10,
    right:10
});
